<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 379, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
February/March 2017

2 hours

Candidates answer on the Question Paper.

No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 325, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 517]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 359, 543]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 558]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 568, 604, 583]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 759, 598]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 504, 596, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 640, 628, 658]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 670, 518, 704]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 718, 561, 737]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 752, 579, 770]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 780, 536, 814]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 72, 700, 90]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 118, 96, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 479, 137]]<|/det|>
Define _gravitational potential_ at a point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
A rocket is launched from the surface of a planet and moves along a radial path, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 285, 809, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 432, 531, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 922, 514]]<|/det|>
The planet may be considered to be an isolated sphere of radius \(R\) with all of its mass \(M\) concentrated at its centre. Point A is a distance \(R\) from the surface of the planet. Point B is a distance \(4R\) from the surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 527, 181, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 527, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
Show that the difference in gravitational potential \(\Delta \phi\) between points A and B is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 567, 546, 594]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta \phi = \frac{3GM}{10R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 603, 504, 621]]<|/det|>
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 774, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
The rocket motor is switched off at point A. During the journey from A to B, the rocket has a constant mass of \(4.7 \times 10^{4} \text{kg}\) and its kinetic energy changes from \(1.70 \text{TJ}\) to \(0.88 \text{TJ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
For the planet, the product \(G M\) is \(4.0 \times 10^{14} \text{N} \text{m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 1}\). It may be assumed that resistive forces to the motion of the rocket are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 735, 183]]<|/det|>
Use the expression in **(b)**(i) to determine the distance from A to B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 737, 92]]<|/det|>
The first law of thermodynamics can be represented by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 103, 551, 122]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta U = q + w.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 601, 152]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the symbols in the expression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 200, 183]]<|/det|>
<form>+\(\Delta U\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 180, 214]]<|/det|>
<form>+\(q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 185, 245]]<|/det|>
<form>+\(W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 242, 920, 261]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 148, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 873, 291]]<|/det|>
A fixed mass of an ideal gas undergoes a cycle ABCA of changes, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 300, 656, 551]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 566, 531, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 181, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 598, 865, 617]]<|/det|>
During the change from A to B, the energy supplied to the gas by heating is 442J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 629, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
Use the first law of thermodynamics to show that the internal energy of the gas increases by 265J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 831, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 866, 91]]<|/det|>
During the change from B to C, the internal energy of the gas decreases by 313 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
By considering molecular energy, state and explain qualitatively the change, if any, in the temperature of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 303, 180, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
For the change from C to A, use the data in **(b)(i)** and **(b)(ii)** to calculate the change in internal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 412, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<form>change in internal energy = .................................................... J [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 444, 181, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the gas at point A is \(227^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Calculate the number of molecules in the fixed mass of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>number = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A uniform beam is clamped at one end. A metal block of mass \(m\) is fixed to the other end of the beam causing it to bend, as shown in Fig.3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 907, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 273, 532, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
The block is given a small vertical displacement and then released so that it oscillates with simple harmonic motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 593, 370]]<|/det|>
The acceleration \(a\) of the block is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[458, 377, 541, 405]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\frac{k}{m} x\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant for the beam and \(x\) is the vertical displacement of the block from its equilibrium position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 146, 478]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
Explain how it can be deduced from the expression that the block moves with simple harmonic motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 146, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 599, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
For the beam, \(k = 4.0 \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{s}^{-2}\). Show that the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 640, 541, 670]]<|/det|>
\[\omega = \frac{2.0}{\sqrt{m}}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 831, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 643, 89]]<|/det|>
The initial amplitude of the oscillation of the block is \(3.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 863, 119]]<|/det|>
Use the expression in **(b)** to determine the maximum kinetic energy of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 241, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>maximum kinetic energy = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 146, 290]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
Over a certain interval of time, the maximum kinetic energy of the oscillations in **(c)** is reduced by \(50\%\) . It may be assumed that there is negligible change in the angular frequency of the oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 332, 473, 349]]<|/det|>
Determine the amplitude of oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 440, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<form>amplitude = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 471, 146, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Permanent magnets are now positioned so that the metal block oscillates between the poles, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 510, 688, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 698, 532, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 726, 920, 760]]<|/det|>
The block is made to oscillate with the same initial amplitude as in **(c)**. Use energy conservation to explain why the energy of the oscillations decreases more rapidly than in **(d)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 904, 920, 922]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 798, 89]]<|/det|>
Explain the main principles of the generation of ultrasound waves for medical use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 384, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>

<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
State **three** advantages of an optic fibre compared to a metal wire for the transmission of a signal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 917, 138]]<|/det|>
1. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 917, 166]]<|/det|>
2. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 917, 198]]<|/det|>
3. ..........................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 148, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
An optic fibre of length \(57\mathrm{km}\) is connected between a transmitter and a receiver, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 268, 878, 373]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 386, 530, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
The attenuation per unit length of the optic fibre is \(0.50 \text{dB} \text{km}^{-1}\). The transmitter provides an input signal of power \(15 \times 10^{-3} \text{W}\) to the fibre. The noise power at the receiver is \(9.0 \times 10^{-7} \text{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 181, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 902, 484]]<|/det|>
Show that the signal power \(P\) entering the receiver from the optic fibre is \(2.1 \times 10^{-5} \text{W}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 558, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 181, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
